title: pm conservative party brexit james forsyth opinion
story: Despite her best efforts, May leaves behind no legacy.She’ll be remembered as the Prime Minister who, more than anything , failed to deliver Brexit.But the Tory party must learn from her failures.If it does not, then Jeremy Corbyn will be in Number  soon enough.May’s premiership was crippled by the  General Election. Her loss of the Tory majority robbed her of her authority, boxed her in on Brexit and discredited her domestic policy agenda.The failure of that campaign carries an important lesson for the Tories — they need a happy warrior.May looked deeply uncomfortable on the campaign trail, with the result that the more the public saw of her, the less they liked.This Tory need for a good campaigner is heightened by the fact that their next leader will have to fight on two fronts, against both Jeremy Corbyn and Nigel Farage.On Brexit, May’s biggest problem was not knowing what she wanted. She triggered Article , the two-year process for leaving the EU that we had to request a humiliating delay to, without a clear idea of the kind of relationship she wanted — and how to get it.This meant that the UK wasted valuable negotiating time and ceded the initiative to the EU in the talks.The Tories need a leader with a plan. Whoever succeeds May will have to know what they want to get out of the EU and how they plan to get it. Given Brussels’ intransigence in these talks, they are also going to need Plans B, C and D.One of May’s other failings was that she didn’t understand one of the key purposes of preparations for No Deal.It wasn’t because you actually wanted — or thought you would end up with — No Deal. It was meant to secure a better deal.The leadership contest, overseen by party chairman Brandon Lewis, will take around six weeks.Any Tory MP can enter the race, and the list of contenders is then whittled down by the parliamentary party.MPs vote in multiple rounds, eliminating one candidate each time until just two are left.The partys , activists then choose behind the final shortlist of two, with the winner declared leader and Prime Minister.When Mrs May became leader, she didnt have to submit to a vote of members because Andrea Leadsom pulled out of the race.So the last time activists have had a say on the leadership was , when David Cameron defeated David Davis.If the UK had been more visibly prepared to walk away, then the EU would have been more constructive in the negotiations.The new Prime Minister must spend the summer examining the state of our no-deal preparations.Absurdly, the Brexit delay has not been used as a chance to improve the UK’s no-deal planning but rather as an excuse to soft pedal. That must change.May’s other great failure has been failing to build a team or create a sense of collective endeavour.Both the disastrous  manesto and her Brexit plan were executed with far too little Cabinet involvement.She sent civil servants to do the very political job of negotiating. The result was a deal that was, unsurprisingly, politically tone deaf.May’s successor must appoint a Cabinet of all the Tory talents — and let them do their jobs.And we need a Brexit Secretary who actually negotiates with Brussels.The Tories have no perfect candidate for No . No one fully fulfils all of these requirements.But a Prime Minister who could deliver Brexit would give the Tories a fighting chance.THE way to think about the Tory leadership contest is that it is like a tournament with two sides of the draw, with each side sending one candidate into the final membership round.One side of the draw is for full-on Brexiteers.Here Boris Johnson, Dominic Raab, Andrea Leadsom, Steve Baker and Esther McVey will duke it out.The other side of the draw features the Cabinet candidates: Jeremy Hunt, Sajid Javid, Michael Gove, Matt Hancock and Rory Stewart.Whoever comes out of the Brexit side of the draw will go into the final round as the strong favourite, given how Tory members just want the UK to get out of the EU.I understand that Boris Johnson has edged ahead of Dominic Raab on this side of the contest.But he will, in the words of one key MP, need to be “materially ahead” of Raab on the first round.Why  Because Raab is more likely to pick up support as more hardline Brexiteer candidates such asRaab’s pitch will be that the Conservative Party is toastit cannot deliver Brexit – and that he is the man to do that.He will argue that other candidates might be better known than him, but Boris’s celebrity won’t save the Toriesthey cannot get Brexit done.But one of Boris’s advantages over Raab is that he has more reach into the rest of the party.His campaign is beginning to pick up support from former Remainer ministers, who see the former London Mayor as the Tories’ best chance of seeing off the twin threats of Corbyn and Farage.At the same time, some on the left of the party have decided that stopping Raab – who they see as a down-the-line right-winger – is now their priority, rather than blocking Boris.ON the Cabinet side of the contest, the question is whether Michael Gove can overhaul Jeremy Hunt.The Foreign Secretary currently has more MPs backing him than anyone  in the Cabinet.But his campaign has had a bumpy few weeks, and some of his supporters are beginning to peel away.This, perhaps, explains why Hunt felt the need to confirm that he was standing just hours after Theresa May announced her resignation yesterday.Part of Hunt’s problem with MPs is that it is very hard to see him beating Boris Johnson or Dominic Raab when it comes to the party members.Their experience with Theresa May has made the membership very wary of former Remainers.GEORGE Osborne has finally had his revenge on Theresa May.He sent a text to a slew of Cabinet leadership hopefuls saying that a big prize awaited the minister who went and told May that the Withdrawal Agreement Bill had to be pulled.Several recipients of this text were amused when Sajid Javid, who was one of Osborne’s junior ministers at the Treasury, then went to demand that May shelve the second referendum part of the bill.SOME members of the  parliamentary intake are considering running for the leadership.They should hold their horses – the new leader will need more than four years of parliamentary experience.But whoever becomes the new PM needs to freshen up the Cabinet, to bring in this new talent.After nine years in government, there are too many administrators in Cabinet and not enough doers.It needs an injection of energy and fresh ideas.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may finally shows emotion too late
story: She’d announced her resignation, laid out her achievements in office and was in the closing seconds of telling the nation she felt no ill will now her premiership is at an end.Then the chin started to wobble, the voice cracked and, as she emotionally emphasised the words “the country I love”, her real feelings emerged.Only the hardest of hearts could fail to feel sorry for her particularly as, unlike other Prime Ministers in the past, she chose to stand outside Downing Street alone.There was pain in that last sentence, a deep-seated fondness for Britain, and an over-whelming sense that she clearly feels a burning sense of injustice at how she’s perceived by her many detractors — myself among them.But no one has ever questioned Mrs May’s sense of duty to her country.In fact, as many of her political colleagues flocked to lavish post-resignation praise, the recurring theme was that of “dedicated public servant”.Admirable, yes, and probably makes you a “strong and stable” MP for Maidenhead.But when it comes to leading the country, that elusive “X Factor” is needed.In fact,she had shown just one small flash of that “country I love” passion in her dealings with the EU she might have successfully delivered Brexit and stayed in the top job for many more years.Instead, she became known as the “Maybot” thanks to her robotic delivery of speeches and failure to communicate effectively with the electorate and even her own cabinet colleagues.It’s a shame, because women in particular will know the sacrices she has made in becoming only the second female Prime Minister in an arena still dominated by machismo.But in the end, it wasn’t enough.You need imagination and breadth of vision to lead the country through Brexit and sadly Ms May had neither.So yes, I’m sorry to see her obvious distress.But I’m not sorry to see her go. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sun says theresa may best wasnt nearly enough
story: For all that her critics have thrown at her, The Sun included, who could fail to recognise the monstrous strain she has endured for three years Or her overwhelming sorrow at giving up the job she has wanted her whole le, with so little to show for it This PM will be remembered now for her failure to deliver Brexit. It will be ungenerous not to remember too her unshakeable dedication to her country and remarkable perseverance against what became insurmountable odds.She is a good person. She did her best.But she is a poor Prime Minister and the author of her own downfall. She appointed a Cabinet of loyal friends largely devoid of talent.She credulously swallowed bad advice from a staunchly europhile and dysal civil service.She lacked vital traits for a leader: core beliefs, confidence, decisiveness, mental agility, communication skills and a willingness to trust and delegate.These failings, and a suicidal manesto, were exposed at the  election. Stripped of her majority, she foolishly tried to pretend “nothing has changed” and made promises she couldn’t keep.She negotiated a Brexit deal which was bad enough even before Monday’s final, fatal compromises.Mrs May described what she sees as her legacy. It is thin gruel. The economy is doing fine, the job market booming. But she did next to nothing for Sun readers, for the “just about managings”.Brexit is undone, like her “social justice” agenda. Our democracy is in disarray, Britain ided, her party at historic poll lows. She leaves her successor an even more colossal task than her own.Whoever that is must, above all, stop Corbyn’s thuggish extremists winning power.That can only be done by delivering Brexit — yes, with No Dealneed be — and somehow seeing off the Brexit Party whose surge could let Corbyn in.Winning the battle of ideas against the Marxist Left will be far simpler. Who is best placed to do it It must be a Brexiteer ready to appoint a younger, fresher, far more talented top team. There are plenty of able Tories in the ranks, their paths blocked by ­Cabinet duds who must be swept away.Leave-backing MPs must avoid splitting their vote and letting another Remainer into No. The party may not survive it.Nor, we believe, will its members tolerate any attempt by MPs to block their favourite candidates. They now have Nigel Farage’s party to join.Mrs May has left the Tories in dire straits and with one chance to survive.For their sake — and Britain’s — they had better make the right choice.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: opinion pay gap unfair bbc
story: The latest instalment of the saga, in which women are somehow seen as less valuable than men, took place when a BBC manager turned down a promotion after discovering she was offered £, less than a man doing exactly the same job.So she tried to get her employer to equalise her salary and they upped their offer a bit, but there was still a £, disparity.So Karen Martin, a radio producer and news editor, sent an email to colleagues explaining that she couldn’t accept the role of deputy editor in the radio newsroom after learning that a man, appointed at the same time, had been offered a higher wage.To a degree, of course, it’s up to the inidual to negotiate their salary. Andyou are paid less than someone  because they are better than you then that is OK. But that is apparently not the case here.“Despite being awarded the same job, on the same day, after the same board, during the same recruitment process, BBC News asked me to accept a considerably lower salary than my male counterpart. A lot less,” Karen told colleagues by email.“I’ve been assured our roles and responsibilities are the same. I’ve also been told my appointment was ‘very well deserved’. It’s just that I’m worth £, less.“Over the past four months I have asked BBC News to think again. And they’ve inched their offer up . . . now the gap is nearer to £,. But for me it has never been about the actual salary. It has been about equal pay.”She also said she had turned down the job on principle after discussing the matter with her young daughters, which led her to conclude that she must “stand up for what is right”.And, to my mind, that is the real nub of this story.Her two daughters, aged seven and , said this to her: “You always tell us to stand up for what is right. If it means less pocket money or not going on holiday, we don’t mind.What matters to us is that when we grow up, we want to be paid the same as a man for the same job.”How poignant — and how powerful. Sometimes you have to see things through the eyes of children to realise there is only one course of action.It makes me think of that phrase: Strong women — may we know them, may we be them, and may we raise them.Well, Karen is certainly raising them. And her brave decision means that her children won’t be as subservient as the women of our generation.To an extent, women have always just accepted the status quo when it comes to men being paid more. But that’s changingStill, what Karen did by refusing the job and sending that email is brave. Most people don’t like to rock the boat, which sometimes means we accept things that should be unacceptable.And women, especially mothers, are often so grateful to have a job that they don’t question it. That’s especially the case for single working mums, as Karen is.Most single working mums simply can’t afford not to work, so they put up and shut up. But that expectation that women should accept less than they are worth makes my blood boil.Can you imagine, by the way,it had emerged that men were routinely being paid less than women  Would we ever hear the end of it Not until equality came. So maybe we all need to think like men for a bit.By rocking the boat, Karen is taking one for the team. She will be no doubt be seen as a troublemaker by some potential employers. But it’s not until people make stands like this that change happens.Despite the furore, the gender pay gap is still everywhere, and it’s not until people say, “No more” that things will change. The bottom line is that women need to start feeling a bit more entitled.We need to know our worth and not be afraid to ask for it. Because the sad truth is that people will pay you less than you are worththey can get away with it. So let’s not be muggins enough to accept it, eh HAVE you been following the story of chef Gary Usher, who was asked by a homeless man called Derickhe had any jobs in his restaurant He offered Derick a job as a kitchen porter. And then tweeted about it because he was happy to have done a good deed.His tweet then went viral. And then suddenly people started accusing him of exploiting homeless people to publicise his restaurant.But given the fact that Usher has declined every single one of the many invitations he has had to go on TV to talk about this story that is so patently untrue.And also, regardless of whether he publicised it or not, there is no doubt that he did a good thing.Still, he has been roundly vilied for what was evidently a kind-hearted gesture.Social media has made us into a nation of cynics and critics. The saying “no good deed goes unpunished” seems very true on this occasion.LOTS of teenagers will no doubt be envious to hear about Benjy Fish, the -year-old from Middlesex who has dropped out of school after being encouraged by his mother – to become a professional gamer.Benjy, who has so far earned £, playing Fortnite, is ranked among the best in the world.And he has guaranteed himself another £, by qualying for this year’s Fortnite World Cup, which boasts a prize pool of £million.He’ll be competing at the event in New York this July, which may sound like the dream for some, and I wish him all the best.But has any parent ever uttered the words: “I hope my son quits school at  to become a professional gamer”  I seriously doubt it.NO doubt the critics will line up to bemoan the fact that Davina McCall is dating again after her orce from Matthew Robertson.She is seeing her long-term friend and hairdresser, Michael Douglas, who she has known for more than  years.All I can think about is just how daunting it must be to put yourself “out there” and start dating again after  years of marriage and three kids.Add to that the burden of being famous, which makes it hard to join Tinder .But we should all wish Davina well – good for her for giving herself another chance at happiness and finding love again. She turned  in October and has got a whole new chapter of her le to live. Why should that be alone Divorcees out there should take heart. You are entitled to happiness. You might just want to go and have a bit of fun by putting yourself out there without waiting for Mr Perfect.Or the love of your le might already be under your nose, like Davina’s hairdresser.What could be better than getting together with an old friend, because he knows the real her. But also, possibly best of all, no more bad hair days.I HAVE no idea what is being shown at the Cannes Film Festival­ – these days it’s much more about the red-carpet dresses than the actual movies.And wow, were there some dresses this year.Alessandra Ambrosio, , and Sharon Stone, , dazzled in little red numbers.The most amazing thing is that there is  years between them. What is Sharon Stone’s secret  She never ages.SO sad reading about Jasmine Bush, the -year old schoolgirl who threw herself in front of a train on the day she was due to receive the grades for her GCSEs in .She had been suffering with ious mental health issues, including anxiety, and had been on medication to help control the symptoms.But she had also been smoking marijuana to relieve anxiety symptoms. Except it clearly had the opposite effect. This story is every parent’s nightmare.Smoking weed is seen as innocent and has been normalised by the fact that “everyone does it”. But it is illegal for a reason.Marijuana is known to make people paranoid and, far from curing anxiety, it exacerbates it. We should bring back that old campaign: “Just say no.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: know mrs may has given her all
story: Events are moving fast enough to make your head spin. Since March , the day the UK should have left the EU, there has been a growing sense of political crisis.Brexit wasn’t happening and the government’s impressive achievements were being lost in the fog. If government was telling people about the growing economy, unemployment falling to its lowest since  or the UK attracting more inward investment in the last year than any other country in the world – no-one was listening.Theresa May was rightly committed to building a majority in parliament for something that would at least complete the first stage of Brexit and allow a new leader to negotiate the future relationship without constant battles in parliament getting in the way.But when she started offering concessions to Jeremy Corbyn’s far left outfitt, the mood in the Tory party darkened.As Chairman of the Parliamentary Conservative Party - the “ Committee” - I had to balance two very strong demands from my colleagues.Firstly, with the failure to exit the EU and the loss of so many brilliant councillors in local elections at the beginning of May, a majority of Conservative MPs had decided that a change of leader was essential.Secondly, most of my colleagues also took the view that Theresa should be allowed the space to leave the stage with dignity.However disappointed or angry people are that we are stuck in a logjam, they know that Mrs May has given it her all. Her dogged determination and absolute commitment to the service of our country have been obvious to everyone.It was sad and painful to be there at the moment that she said she would resign as leader of the party and no one could fail to be moved by her parting words outside No. The ConservativeParty knew that change was needed but I am glad that the process has begun with decency and respect.Some people inside and outside parliament have talked about me being a candidate for leader. As Chairman of the  Committee I would have been in charge of the election process so I stood down with immediate effect so that everything can be seen to be above board.I can now consider my position unconstrained. Whoever stands – and whoever wins, the task is a big one. It is nothing less than restoring the broken trust in British politics.We have to leave the EU as we promised we would and then get back to a radical agenda to let people take back control of their lives. Politicians need to talk less about social mobility and do more to make sure that everyone in our great country can make the most of their talents.The crucial starting point must be to reunite the Conservative Party: faced with the most extreme socialist threat that would destroy business, jobs and savings we owe it not to ourselves but to every decent hardworking citizen.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: beautiful baby boy born 10 weeks premature without any skin defies the odds to finally return home
story: Kaiden Shattock arrived with a mystery condition which left him looking like a “piece of uncooked meat”.The tot was born without a top layer of skin - meaning he could not be held by proud parents Jessica Kibbler and Jake Shattock, both , for  days.Kaiden, weighing lb oz, was in such a state that even the maternity nurses had to leave the ward to break down in tears.Jessica, from Leamington Spa, Warks, told the Daily Star: “When the nurses took us into the room to introduce us to Kaiden for the first time he was red raw, like a piece of uncooked meat.“Jake and I cried, but even the nurses left the room and cried their eyes out because they didn’t know what to say to us, and didn’t know how  to help him.”Doctors warned the young couple that their new bundle of joy probably “wouldn’t survive”.But Kaiden was placed on a series of medication while staff worked to reduce the tots pain – with the only skin he had left on his face.His condition was caused by a kidney complication Jessica suffered during her pregnancy called hydronephrosis.The young mum also suffered bleeding before going into labour at Nottingham City Hospital, on November .After six painful weeks, Kaiden started to grow skin but it was still too risky to put him in clothes.But earlier this month he had his first ever skin graft and will have a further four operations over the next year, the Star reports.Little trooper Kaiden has not had an easy start to le fighting sepsis, necrotising enterocolitis, congential herpes, dermolysis and bronchiolitis.He’s been back to hospital six times and was also diagnosed with a hearing impairment in both his ears.But his mum said the little lad is still a joy to be around.She added: “He’s got the loveliest smile and the prettiest laughyou get him going. title: legal firm four day week pay rise plymouth
story: The sht in work days at Portcullis Legals saw the Plymouth firm become the first workplace in south west England to convert to four-day work weeks.Managing director Trevor Worth said: The initial results have been heartening - our team is happier and our customers are receiving a better service.Bosses at Portcullis Legals said staff and customers are happier after the change, which sees the office open later into the evening.The firm raised pay to eliminate concerns that the change in hours might just be a cost-cutting exercise.Successful schemes that have been tested around the world have seen employees working fewer hours but being more productive with their time.Bosses say the change has boosted morale and motivation.A study of a trial at a New Zealand financial firm found workers were % more productive - improving both profits and staff well-being, reported Plymouth Live.Seeing the results, the bosses at Portcullis ran its own five-month trial.The company, which has nine staff and works from the innovative Law Store in Plymstock, is now fully implementing the initiative.Mr Worth said: I’ve contacted businesses far and wide to find out the benefits and pitfalls of the four-day week, working with academics and industry leaders to find out the best way to apply the four-day week to Portcullis.The response has been extraordinary and there’s a real passion to help other firms achieve a happier working week for their staff.Our staff have been more motivated and productive - I’m delighted we’ve been able to make it work and provide an even better service for customers, and a great working environment for our team. title: galapagos islands rare animals thriving
story: If ever there was a good place to forget about Brexit, then this is it.I am writing this on board Coral , a splendid motor vessel which for the past seven days has conveyed my we and me, together with a small group of fellow enthusiasts, on our voyage around six of the  main islands that make up the Galapagos archipelago.For the whole of our time here, we have been lucky to have as our guide and mentor Jorge Torres Pallo — the former distinguished Governor of Galapagos — now a senior adviser to the Galapagos National Park.He has an eye like a Galapagos hawk.Yesterday morning, for example, we disembarked from our panga, a small outboard-powered boat, to trek through thickets on the northwest coast of Santa Cruz Island.“That’s the small ground finch, one of Darwin’s finches,” Jorge said, pointing to a tiny, dark bird flitting from branch to branch in the trees above us.“Darwin studied  types of tree finch in the islands.“If he hadn’t noticed that dferent types of finches on dferent islands had dferent-shaped beaks as a result of eating dferent food, we would never have had the Theory of Evolution.”One of Darwin’s finches! I couldn’t believe it.I pointed my camera at it and clicked.These Darwinian resonances are of consuming interest.Galapagos itself is today engaged in some kind of Darwinian struggle for survival.For centuries, the islands’ resources were plundered.The population of giant tortoises, for example, which at one time numbered more than ,, was reduced to a tenth of that size.Whaling fleets put in for supplies of fresh meat and the giant tortoises were an obvious and easy target.Tortoise oil lit the lamps in Quito, Ecuador’s burgeoning capital city.Even more signicant, perhaps, was the collateral damage that centuries of exploitation created, particularly as a result of the impacts of invasive species.Feral cats, rats, dogs, pigs and donkeys wrought havoc even after the ships that first brought them had long since disappeared.The plunder wasn’t limited to the land. The health of the seas surrounding the islands was put at risk through illegal and uncontrolled exploitation of the islands’ marine resources.When I first visited Galapagos, almost  years ago, it struck me that the islands’ future was truly balanced on a kne-edge.Though serious attempts were being made to deal with the underlying problems, particularly the impact of invasive species and overfishing, there was still a long way to go.And there were new menaces. Galapagos, or so it seemed, might become the victim of its own success, as tourists by the thousand were poised to overwhelm the islands’ ability to cope.Marine pollution too, including from plastic waste, was another factor to contend with.“The irony of plastic waste in the Galapagos,” Jorge explained to me one evening, “is that a large proportion is generated internationally, outside the islands but brought by ocean currents to our shores.”Even nine years ago, when my we and I last visited Galapagos, it wasn’t clear to me that the corner had been turned.Admittedly, the arrival of cruise liners had been prohibited. Sophisticated methods had been introduced to handle the flow of tourists and new rules prevented, or at least reduced, immigration from mainland Ecuador.On the ground, a radical programme to deal with invasive species was achieving impressive results.On Isabela Island, for example, New Zealand sharp-shooters, patrolling in helicopters, had effectively eradicated the islands’ once-teeming population of feral goats.But still it seemed to me very much a touch-and-go affair. Even as one problem was dealt with, others raised their heads. Though progress had been made as far as the control of invasive species was concerned, there was still a long way to go before every last cat, goat, rat or feral pig was eliminated from the islands.Nor was the problem limited to animals. You had to deal with insects too. A nasty fly , another non-native pest, was attacking the chicks of Darwin’s finches, with horrendous effects.Then there were the invasive plants. Some of them, such as the Himalayan hill raspberry, seem to be as hard to control as Japanese knotweed — and just as devastating.On this latest visit, I have been impressed by how much progress is being made since I was last here. In spite of dire forecasts, the cruise ships are still not disgorging boatloads of passengers. The many tourists who do come, while welcome for the vital income, are carefully managed.And the fight against invasive species is still being prosecuted with determination. If the habitat can be safeguarded, endangered species may once more thrive.Take the giant tortoise, for example, that iconic symbol of Galapagos.We spent an afternoon at the Charles Darwin Research Centre in Puerto Ayora, Santa Cruz.It is an internationally supported institution, which for the past  years has been at the heart of the effort to restore all the still extant species of giant tortoise to their traditional habitats on the ious islands.The animals mate, eggs are laid and hatched and young tortoises reared until they are old and strong enough to be released into the wild. Or take an avian species on the brink of extinction: The wonderful Floreana mockingbird.On the third day of our voyage, we spent an hour snorkeling off tiny Champion Island, just off Floreana.From time to time I took off my mask to stare at the cactus on Champion’s clftops, hoping against hope to glimpse a Floreana mockingbird.I knew it would be a long shot. Ironically, the Floreana mockingbird, one of three mockingbird species studied by Darwin in the Galapagos, is actually extinct on Floreana itself.But around  to  birds are to be found on nearby Gardner islet, with another tiny population of around  to  birds surviving on Champion Island.Amazingly, as I climbed back into the panga, I caught sight of a small bird on the nearby clf, darting from one prickly cactus to another.“Look there!” I pointed. “Isn’t that a Floreana mockingbird ”Jorge took out his binoculars. “I think it is.”I couldn’t believe my luck. There are around , bird species in the world and the Floreana mockingbird is one of the rarest you will ever encounter.Bringing it back to Floreana will be a long, tough job.It’s not just a question of getting rid of the rats which prey on the eggs and the chicks.The Opuntia cactus, whose flowers are the Floreana mockingbird’s staple food and which has been largely eaten out by goats, must be re-established too.As I look back at the week that has just passed, I think of the magnicent wildle we have seen — iguanas on land and sea, albatrosses, petrels and flamingos, blue- and red-footed boobies, frigatebirds, pelicans, sea lions, whitetip reef sharks and marine turtles to name but a few.But that brief and fleeting vision of the Floreana mockingbird is perhaps my most vivid memory of all.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: The Conservatives have been battered. title: boy 14 becomes full time
story: NewsBoy, , becomes full time carer for his young siblings after dad walks outEmma Lowe, , from Preston, Lancashire has praised her son Harry for taking on the role of man of the houseShareCommentsByAnn CusackLaura Forsyth:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsHarry puts in a -hour day to help with his siblings Arthur and Alfies care "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A schoolboy has become a full time carer for his five siblings after his dad walked out on the family. Emma Lowe, , who is a single mum of seven – including twins with Downs Syndrome - has paid tribute to her son Harry.The -year-old has been putting in a  hour day to help with their care - taking on the role of aposman of the houseapos. Harryaposs siblings are Thomas, , Benjamin, , twins Arthur and Alfie, six, and four-year-old Elsie. Emma tragically lost a daughter, Molly, aged five months, who also had Downs Syndrome. Her husband walked out soon after her youngest child was born – leaving Emma to cope alone. The former teacher, from Preston, Lancashire, said: “It was a very daunting prospect, especially with two disabled children. “But Harry stepped in and became the man of the house. He is absolutely incredible and I couldn’t cope without him.    “Most -year-olds are out with their mates, having fun, or lazing around. But Harry never gets a minute to himself. He looks out for the twins all the time, just like a parent would. I would just like him to get the credit and the recognition he deserves.” Emma’s heartache began when her daughter, Molly, was born in March , and diagnosed with Downs Syndrome, a hole in the heart and underdeveloped lungs. She died five months later. Emma said: It was heartbreaking and very hard for my older children. We call Molly’s grave her ‘forever bed’ and we visit her all the time.” Emma’s twin sons, Alfie and Arthur, were born in July , and she was stunned when they, too, were diagnosed with Downs Syndrome. She says: “The chances of having three babies with Downs Syndrome were a million to one. But when the midwe held Alfie up, I recognised the features, just like Molly. The condition itself didn’t scare me because I knew I could cope but I was scared, after losing Molly, that the same thing might happen again.”    Arthur and Alfie thankfully did not have the same medical challenges as Molly, though they were later diagnosed with autism. They are also non-verbal and need wheelchairs. The year after the twins were born, Emma had a daughter, Elsie. But without warning, her husband, David, walked out. Her eldest son, Thomas, also left home to go to college – leaving Harry as man of the house. Emma says: “Harry just naturally fell into the role of young carer. It wasn’t what I wanted for him and I certainly didn’t push him into it.  “But he loved caring for the boys and he quickly became invaluable. I really couldn’t cope without him now. “Harry and Alfie in particular have a very special bond. Alfie is completely non-verbal except for one word: ‘Harry.’ Unlike most boys his age, Harry is up at .am to bath and dress his brothers. He will then help feed them whilst having his own breakfast and getting ready for school. Emma says: “By the time he goes to school, he has often been on the go for three hours, watching the twins, keeping them safe, playing with them, and then lting them onto their school bus when it comes.”    And the evenings are just as hectic. Emma, said: “Harry will change nappies, wash clothes, cook meals. He can cook steak and spaghetti Bolognese. “He helps put the twins to bed with me and then, late at night, we will reheat our evening meal and eat together. It can be midnight by the time our tasks are all finished. “Even during the night,the twins wake up crying, he is there with them. I try to make sure he gets his sleep but he wants to look after them. “And when we go out, Harry is on hand to make sure the twins have a good time. He puts them before himself every time. “They both need wheelchairs for any distances so Harry will push one, I push the other, and Benjamin looks out for Elsie.” Harry is anxious to change the stigma around Downs Syndrome and is involved in support groups and charity work.    Emma says: “Harry has even given talks on his brothers. He wants to make people more aware and more accepting. “People have no idea what le is like for him – and other young carers. He adores his brothers but looking after them is demanding and dficult sometimes. “But I know he wouldn’t change them for the world.” Harry says: “When I say I’m a carer, most people presume I look after a parent, but I look after my siblings. I think siblings who care for siblings don’t get the support or the recognition they need. “I don’t get asked to do this. I do it to support my brothers and to help my mum. My mum does a great job, she’s a superhero, and I hope, through telling my story, I can raise awareness of the need for more help and support.”

title: british spies smuggled secrets putins
story: NewsBritish spies smuggled secrets about Putins new supersonic bomber using loose teaRussian air crews unwittingly helped to smuggle Russian defence intelligence into the hands of British spiesShareCommentsByKaisha Langton:,  MAY NewsThe plan was carried out unwittingly by Russian pilots who journeyed to Venezuela with the tea "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBritish spies managed to smuggle secrets about multi-million pound upgrades to Russiaaposs supersonic bombers out of the country using an unusual method - through loose leaf tea, it has emerged. The audacious plan was carried out unwittingly by Russian pilots who journeyed to Venezuela with the tea, where an agent then picked up the discarded box. The information was then used by Western forces to help identy vulnerabilities in the planes, an intelligence source revealed.British spies from MI worked with the CIA and Mossad, the national intelligence agency of Israel to hatch the plans, MailOnline reports. The aim was to find out more about Russiaaposs supersonic TU- bombers, known as Blackjacks.   The plot involved a Russian crew drinking tea during a flight from Russia to Caracas with secrets stashed at the bottom of the packet by a Western source placed in Russia.According to The Sunday Express , the bomberaposs upgrades have transformed its defensive capabilities which make it dficult for enemy fighters to lock onto it.In the wake of the Novichok attack in Salisbury last year, diplomatic tensions between Russia and the West are fraught and the intelligence agencies had to come up with a plan to extract information whilst avoiding sending spies into the country. A solution came in the most quintessentially of British solutions - tea.  Spies discovered Putin was sending two Blackjacks to Venezuela in a show of support to President Nicolas Maduro in December, . Russia relies upon the re-selling of Venezuelan oil and gas and had signed a pact with Hugo Chavez in .Putin seized the opportunity to display the bombers off the US coast and so a plan was then hatched for the information to be carried unknowingly on one of these Blackjacks.It was stored at the bottom of a packet of loose Russian Caravan tea that was on board the bomber aircraft. Agents even had to calculate how much tea the pilots would drink during the -hour flight.  If there was too much, the packet would not be thrown away.  When the plane landed at Simon Boli airport in Venezuela, an agent retrieved the discarded packet and then took it to a CIA officer waiting at a hotel in Caracas. The secrets were taken to the US for analysis before it was shared with UK and Nato forces. An intelligence source told MailOnline:  An hour after landing, a quantity of rubbish, which included the tea packet, was taken from the aircraft while it was being refuelled. The packet, which contained a small amount of tea, was among items placed in a rubbish disposal point. That it worked was due, in no small part, to luck, but such is the way with many operations.apos

title: former deputy head teacher caught
story: NewsFormer deputy head teacher caught drink driving to Aldi with baby in the carSamantha Rae, , was seen swerving across the road with her -month-old son in the car before getting out at her local AldiShareByTom MackKaisha Langton:,  MAY NewsSamantha Rae, , was caught drink driving on her way to the Aldi on Watling Street, Hinckley "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA former deputy head teacher got drunk and drove her toddler son to Aldi so they could get pudding. Samantha Rae, , was swerving across the road and was later seen getting out of her car before tripping up on the kerb. A concerned driver who had been following her along the A near Hinckley called the police as soon as they saw Rae’s -month-old son was also in the car when it stopped at the townaposs local Aldi. The mother was breathalysed and found to be over the drink-driving limit. She was arrested and pleaded guilty to drink-driving on Friday when she appeared at Leicester Magistrates’ Court. Prosecutor Sally Bedford told the court: “It was about .pm on May  when a witness called  having followed this defendant on the A. “They were concerned by the standard of the defendant’s driving.  She was driving on the wrong side of the road and when she pulled over and got out of the car she was staggering all over the place and tripped up the kerb. “There appeared to be a small child with her.” She added that Leicestershire Police attended and found Rae appeared to be “extremely intoxicated”. Ms Bedford said: “She presented as being very much under the influence of alcohol. She was arrested and taken to the police station.” At the police station, the -year-old mum, of Bradgate Road, Hinckley, was breathalysed and found to have a reading of  microgrammes per ml of breath. The legal limit is  microgrammes. Ms Bedford said: “She was interviewed and explained she had too much to drink and decided to drive to Aldi to purchase a dessert for dinner. “She accepted her standard of driving was very poor.  The court heard Rae had been deputy head of a large British school in Shanghai, but had then moved to Indonesia, where she had started drinking a lot. Since moving back to England she had been hoping to get work as a supply teacher, but she said she recognised that with the drink-driving conviction her prospects of employment would be extremely limited now”. Rae, who did not have legal representation, told the magistrates: “I’d just like to apologise profusely for my actions. I’m deeply filled with regret and remorse for putting my child at risk.” She told the court she had been working with the charity Turning Point to address her alcohol problem. She said: “They’re keeping me motivated to stay on track and not drink. “Once again, I can only apologise for my behaviour.” The magistrates ordered Rae to complete  hours of unpaid work and she was disqualied from driving for two years.

story: NewsGirl, , spends school playtimes alone after shes refused electric wheelchairFrancesca Cirillo relies on an adult to push her manual wheelchair around, meaning she struggles to socialise with other pupilsShareCommentsByAlya Zayed:,  MAY NewsFrancesca with her dad Domenico, mum Magdalena, and sister Maria "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A five-year-old girl spends school playtimes on her own after she was aposrefusedapos a powered wheelchair.Francesca Cirillo has spinal muscular atrophytype  which affects her ability to stand or walk. Her dad says she has reached an age where she knows she doesn’t have the same abilities as her friends. As she can walk a few steps at a time, it was reportedly decided she did not qualy for a powered wheelchair which would allow her to move independently and join in with the fun at playtime. Cambridgeshire and Peterborough Wheelchair Services have given her a manual wheelchair which leaves her dependent on an adult to push her around. This means she struggles to socialise with other pupils.Dad Domenico Cirillo told Cambridgeshire Live : “Francesca spends a lot of time by herself.“SMA has really affected her confidence and is holding her back from being able to form social groups, in and out of school – anyone with a five-year-old knows how important that is.”    He added: “Francesca has reached an age where she is starting to ask more questions about her condition – she knows she is dferent, she knows she doesn’t have the same abilities as her friends – but this chair would give her some independence and that is vital for her as she grows.” Her parents have turned to Newle, a charity for disabled children, to raise the money needed for a powered wheelchair. Mr Cirillo said: “We have ploughed all our savings into giving Francesca a safe place to live and making our home more accessible for her. “We just don’t have the money to buy the wheelchair too.”   The company previously providing wheelchair and mobility services to the NHS was Provide, which reportedly shut Francesca’s case saying no further action was required, but AJM Healthcare has taken over since.An AJM Healthcare representative said they will be reopening the case and have booked Francesca in for a new assessment in June. Mr Cirillo said: “Having spoken to the medical team, it might be that they provide some vouchers towards the cost of the chair, and that would help Newle make up the rest of the cost.” He added: “It’s less pressure on the charitythe NHS could provide more support but we’re conscious that the NHS is stretched and we are grateful for whatever we can get.” Cambridgeshire-based charity Wheels for Martin’s Friends has already donated £,, but more is still needed for the £, chair. Any extra funds raised will go to the  other children on the waiting list for specialist equipment in the region.To donate, visit newle.support HelpFran, call Newle on  , text NEWLIFE FRAN to  to give a one-off £ or to  to give £ a month, or email local@newlecharity-has contacted Provide for comment.

story: NewsHatton Garden raider has smuggled £m worth of burglary loot overseasEXCLUSIVE The Met have recovered £m of the total haul from the raid but are still trying to track down booty worth nearly £millionShareCommentsByTom PettorNick Sommerlad:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsJohn Collins, Terry Perkins and Brian Reader in the Castle Public House in May  "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailOne of the Hatton Garden crooks smuggled £million of loot to a Spanish hideaway, it is claimed. The ageing villain recruited major gangland figures to help ship his cut from the infamous £million raid. The Mirror understands the valuables were shipped to Holland before they were moved to Spain. Police have recovered more than £million of the crooks’ total haul, but are still trying to trace booty worth nearly £million. Our revelation comes after millions tuned in on Friday to Ross Kemp’s ITV documentary on the infamous raid, in which a record £million of gems, jewellery, cash and gold was stolen. Kemp’s Hatton Garden: The Inside Story revealed unseen police surveillance footage, secret recordings of the gang’s conversations.    ITV also screened a four-part dramatisation last week, starring Timothy Spall as burglar Terry Perkins and Kenneth Cranham as mastermind Brian Reader. The real-le gang, led by Reader, then , broke into the vault of London’s Hatton Garden Safe Deposit company over the Easter weekend in . On the first night, they entered the building, disabled the lt, climbed down the shaft to the basement, disabled the alarm and drilled three holes through half-a-metre thick concrete. After the ten-tonne jack they were using to topple metal shelving on the other side of the hole broke, the gang ed two nights later – without Reader – to complete the raid. But six of them were caught the following month after one of their vehicles was spotted on CCTV by police.    Reader, Perkins, then aged , John “Kenny” Collins, , Danny Jones, , Carl Wood,  and William “Billy the Fish” Lincoln,  – were jailed for up to seven years each in March  for conspiracy to commit burglary. The final gang member Michael “Basil” Seed, , was arrested last year and jailed in March for  years. Claims that one of the men smuggled £m worth of valuables abroad come in a revised edition of a biography of Brian Reader called One Last Job. A source told the authors: “The gang were made to look like idiots after they were arrested. But nothing could be further from the truth.  “One of them got £million out of the country, through Holland to Spain, and he will be able to enjoy his retirement when it finally begins.” The gang were covertly recorded falling out with each other in the aftermath of the raid, amid suspicions some themselves to a larger share of the spoils. It is possible that claims of loot being moved abroad is a ploy to distract others from the fact that more is hidden closer to home. Jessica Greaves was born with cerebral palsy and has never spoken a word. In the first first five months of her le, her parents Natalie and Matt didn’t knowthey would ever be able to communicate with her. But things changed when they played her a lullaby and she gave a beaming smile.Since then, the family have spoken through the power of music, Birmingham Live reports. Natalie and Matt have played all kinds of  music with Jessica, including musical instruments.Her sister Bethany, , has Downs Syndrome and loves to sing to her.Over time, theyaposve seen Jessica’s tastes change as she has grown up - today, , she loves listening to Ed Sheeran .   The family has recently started working with Soundabout, a charity that empowers children and young people with special needs to communicate through music. The charity worked with Jessica to create a lullaby that says aposI love youapos using sounds. I know about the positives of music for young people, we know how much Jessica gets from it, said Natalie, who is also mum to Megan, . Music is her love, it takes her out of being so trapped. It enables her to communicate and engage.    Natalie, a paramedic from Stourbridge, added: “Jessica had to be resuscitated at birth and suffered severe brain damage. “She cannot talk or walk or use her hands and she has to be fed through a tube. “Everyone was so unsure of her prognosis but when we played her a lullaby on one of her mobile toys we realised there was a way we could communicate with her. “It was something we knew she enjoyed.”  Soundabout invited renowned composers Dame Evelyn Glennie, John Rutter, Will Todd and Debbie Wiseman OBE to work with Jessica to come up with a lullaby that said aposI love youapos using sound alone. “When I saw the video footage of Jessica vocalising and running her fingers along the guitar, I cried and cried, said Natalie. “They used her vocalising sounds to put the lullaby together. “She loves to listen to it, we tell her it’s Jessica’s song and she’s become very attached to it. “She knows her name and she smiles when we say that.” “We can’t communicate with Jessica in any other way, said Natalie.  I know, as her mum, when she’s happy or sad, but it’s lovely for her to be able to express when she likes something. “She smiles and makes happy sounds when we put something on that she likes, it’s like she’s trying to sing, it’s really quite incredible. “If we don’t put music on, saywe’re talking in the car, she’ll shout and shout until we do. We drove to France last summer and I think we know Now  off by heart now. “Bethany loves to sing and dance and she knows she’ll get some much out of Jessica when she does. She says she knows how to make her sister happy.  Music also helps Jessica to understand her daily routine. “It’s had a massive impact on her routine. She likes to listen to Chris Evans on the radio and she associates this with waking up and knows it’s time for us to get her washed and dressed and ready for school. “When she comes home she loves to watch Disney films because they have lots of music in them, and she like Mary Poppins too, that’s her favourite at the moment. “Then we play lullabies at bedtime and she knows that’s time to go to sleep. “Music helps to relax her.”  The family also have bells, a harmonica and a piano for Jessica to play with their help. Jessicaaposs Lullaby forms part of Soundabout’s #ShareTheLove campaign, raising awareness of the vital role that music plays in the lives of people with complex learning disabilities and autism. Revellers going to see Classic Ibiza at Ragley Hall this summer are helping to raise funds for Soundabout.  Clare Cook, CEO of Soundabout said: “Soundabout works to unlock the potential of children, young people and adults with severe and profound learning disabilities through music, and empowers families, carers and teachers to do the same. We believe that every child should have access to meaningful music provision, both for its own sake and to support their wider development. Our recent report “Sounds of Intent in the Early Years” revealed the signicant impact that music has in “closing the developmental gap” especially for children with complex needs. Global’s Make Some Noise is raising funds to support our “Building Bridges” project which focuses on music making during times of particular challenge for children with complex needs and their families - the moment shortly after birth when diagnosis hits, and the transition out of school when these young people reach .”To download Jessica’s lullaby or find out more, click  here

title: nada farhoud urgently need ban
story: NewsopinionNada Farhoud: We urgently need to ban plastics that cannot be recycledIts time we all realised that many of the plastics we faithfully put in our recycling bins are secretly being burnedShareCommentsByNada Farhoud:,  MAY NewsopinionWith bewildering collection systems of multicoloured boxes, bins and bags, it is perhaps not surprising recycling rates have flatlined "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMillions of plastic pots, tubs and trays we diligently put in recycling bins are secretly being incinerated. Fty local authorities admit they are burning “low-grade” packaging made from ­polyethyleneas it’s so brittle it needs to be sent to specialist recycling facilities. The problem is we don’t have any. Until last year, China received two-thirds of it, then it shut up shop. Other countries receiving our waste have also imposed restrictions, leaving us to deal with it. So instead of being turned into products, it is burned to generate electricity. There is a logic to turning waste that can’t be recycled into energy rather than being sent to landfill. But only as the last resort. The  incinerators we have in England produce the same amount of toxic particulates each year as , lorries – contributing to air pollution and greenhouse gas emissions. I try my best to reuse packaging but when I do recycle, I want to know my efforts have not been betrayed by it all being shoved into a furnace.    England is on the brink of burning more rubbish that it recycles. While rates of domestic waste recycling have stalled since , incineration has tripled between   and  , although this is not due to a reluctance to recycle, or to do our bit for the environment. There is a huge gap between the best and worst local authorities. But this doesn’t mean people in Westminster or Birmingham, or any other area with poor recycling rates, can’t be bothered. The system just isn’t working. To find a way out of this pollution crisis we must ­radically reduce how much is produced in the first place. We need to ban plastics that can’t be recycled and businesses should set up proper systems for those that local authorities find most dficult. But in order to be able to stop burning rubbish and dumping it on vulnerable communities abroad, we must also get rid of our ludicrously complex and chaotic recycling system of over  dferent schemes. With bewildering collection systems of multicoloured boxes, bins and bags, it is perhaps not surprising recycling rates have flatlined. A nationally consistent system would mean every household in the country recycling the same items, helped by a set of easily recycled materials.

title: statue best woman footballer world
story: NewsStatue for best woman footballer in the world who was recruited at just As our Lionesses head to France, a statue of the first woman to be inducted into the National Football Museum Hall of Fame will be unveiledShareCommentsByAmanda Killelea:,  MAY NewsLily Parr played for Dick, Kerr Ladies which was run from a munitions factory in Preston, Lancs, where the factory girls took the footballing world by storm "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailChallenged to kick the ball as hard as she could a young Lily Parr squared up to the boy in goal and went for it – breaking his arm and giving birth to a legend. Born in , by the age of  she was recruited to her first woman’s team – one of many created during the First World War – and played for her country not much later in . Standing ft tall, the chain-smoking left-footed winger was an equal to any man – and one of the best players England has produced. In a -year career she scored nearly , goals. As our Lionesses prepare to head to the World Cup in France next month, Lily will become the first female ­footballer to have a statue when a le-size bronze monument is unveiled at Manchester’s National Football Museum in the same month.    Cousin June Patten, , says Lily would be proud but humble about the honour. “She was strong, she was forceful, she was determined,” says June. “It is safe to say she was the best woman ­footballer in the world. “We all knew her as ‘Our Lil” and we are proud that she was one of us. She may have been fearsome on the pitch, but off the pitch she was one of the kindest, most gentle, funny and loveliest people you could have met.” Lily was born in a rented house in St Helens, Merseyside, the fourth of labourer George Parr and his we Sarah’s seven children. She first honed her football skills playing alongside her brothers on waste ground near their rented family home. The local lads soon counted her as their equal with her fearsome reputation on the pitch becoming the stuff of local legend.    June explains: “The boys used to call for her and ask her to play football. She was just accepted as one of the lads. But one of them one day said to her I bet you can’t kick a ball hard. He said I’ll go in goal and you kick the ball at me. She kicked the ball so hard she broke his arm. She had a kick like a mule. She was a better footballer than all the boys.” It wasn’t long before Lily’s talents were spotted. It was towards the end of the First World War and most men were on the frontline fighting. Women took the helm working in mills and munitions factories in tough conditions, so bosses decided that taking up a sport like football in the fresh air would be good for them. So the beautul game became the women’s game with  ladies teams dotted across the country attracting crowds of thousands, and raising money for war charities. Dick, Kerr Ladies was the best of the bunch. It was run from a munitions factory in Preston, Lancs, with the factory girls grafting hard by day and taking the ­footballing world by storm at weekends.    Lily scored an incredible  goals for them in her first season. And she represented England in the first recognised women’s international ­football game, helping her country beat France -. When Dick, Kerr played St Helens Ladies on Boxing Day of , , people flocked to Goodison Park in Liverpool to watch the game, with ­thousands more said to be locked out. But just a year later, in spite of the popularity of women’s football, the ­Football Association banned women’s clubs from its grounds, deeming the sport “quite unsuitable for females”. The ban remained in place until the late s, but that did not stop Lily from continuing to play. She toured abroad with Dick, Kerr, staying with the team until  and scoring more than  goals in her career, making her England’s most prolic goal-scorer of all time. Lily was also known for her aggressive style of play, which didn’t always go down well with the referee or the opposition. In April  Parr and Hilda Durbar of Stoke United were sent off for fighting in Dick, Kerr Ladies’ ­fractious – win before , fans at The Old Recreation Ground.    But she also had a mischievous side – she was rumoured to swipe balls from the field and sell them for profit and asked for her wages to be ­supplemented with her beloved Woodbine cigarettes. June remembers that cheeky streak well, laughing: “She was a chain smoker. One day she was playing and the ball was at the other end of the field. “There was a man leaning over the rail smoking so she took his cigarette off him, took a big drag of it and then gave it him back. “The smoking didn’t seem to bother her though.” Her cousin lived with a woman called Mary, and June recalls: “Everyone was very proud of her. She used to come on a Sunday evening to my grandma’s house, she used to bring her friend Mary who was a lovely lady, she was delightful, and we used to look forward to her coming. “She and Mary were such a joy to be with. In those days people didn’t contemplate it, but looking back now they were very likely to be gay. They were a very happy couple. “But it didn’t register with us – they were just Lily and Mary.” Lily trained as a nurse working at ­Whittingham Mental Hospital, near Preston, until she retired. She died from breast cancer aged  in , but her legend lives on.    She was the first female footballer to be inducted into the Football Hall of Fame in , and next month her statue, commissioned by chocolate makers Mars, will be unveiled. Football historian Gail Newsham, who has written a book about the legendary Dick, Kerr Ladies team, says there is no doubt that Lily was one of ­England’s greatest players of all time. She says: “The power of her shot was always a great asset and her ability. She was naturally gted and fearless. “The longevity of her career makes her stand out too and enabled her to score so many goals. “The fact that she played for so long obviously shows her love of the game. She was always admired by team mates and opponents alike. “People now look up to her as being one of the first ‘stars’ of the game. There can’t be many more players,any, who have scored more goals than Lily did.”And Gail believes England’s ­Lionesses need look no further for inspiration than Lilythey want to bring the World Cup back homethis summer.“If they can believe in their own ability as Lily did in hers, they won’t go far wrong,” she says. “Be fearless and never give up. I am sure the ­Lionesses won’t let Lily, or the rest of the Dick, Kerr Ladies, down. Let’s hope football is coming home.”Get involved in all the action and support England’s Lionesses this summer on social media using the Mars hashtag #SupportHer

story: NewsFBI has tapes of Martin Luther King laughing as woman was raped in front of himThe FBI tried to destroy the reputation of civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr as controversial unearthed files revealShareCommentsByChristopher Bucktin:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsMartin Luther King, Jr. receiving a kiss from his we Coretta Scott King "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailShocking details of the FBI’s smear campaign against Martin Luther King Jr have been found on secret tapes, it is claimed. Its is alleged the agency accused the celebrated civil-rights campaigner of having up to  affairs. As the US Baptist minister rose to prominence in the s and s, he was subjected to years of wiretaps and eavesdropping by infamous intelligence chief J Edgar Hoover, who believed he had Communist Party ties. Details of the covert tapes have been revealed by biographer David Garrow, who says he has unearthed files not scheduled for release until .    The author claims Dr King, who was only  when he was killed on April , , spent  years – almost a third of his le – under the FBI’s watch. The covert surveillance was designed to undermine the civil-rights activist, as Hoover feared his popular movement could destabilise the country. Agents honed in on King’s philandering and claims he fathered a child – claims which Garrow argues could lead to “painful historical reckoning”. Although the tapes, recorded by bugs in two lamps in hotel rooms booked by King in January, , are still kept in a vault at the US National Archives, the author and historian has unearthed the FBI summaries of the ious incidents.    He claims they show King had extramarital affairs with up to  women and, shockingly, even “looked on and laughed” as pastor friend Logan Kearse raped a parishioner. The recording from the Willard Hotel, near the White House, in Washington DC, shows how King was accompanied by Kearse, who died in , along with several female parishioners of his church. In his hotel room, the files claim, they then “discussed which women among the parishioners would be suitable for natural and unnatural sex acts”. The FBI document says, “when one of the women protested that she did not approve, the Baptist minister immediately and forcefully raped her” as King watched. He is alleged to have “looked on, laughed and offered advice” during the attack. Senior FBI officials allegedly later sent a copy of the incriminating tape to King and called him an “evil abnormal beast” and told him his sexual exploits would be “on record for all time”. Mr Garrow said he had no idea of the scale or the ugliness of it, nor of King’s apparent indference to rape until he saw the files. He said: “It poses so fundamental a challenge to his historical stature as to require the most complete and extensive historical review possible.”    Historian and leading American civil rights activist, Edith Lee Payne, told the Mirror she was disgusted at the claims.The -year-old, of Detroit, Michigan, who became the iconic poster girl of the I Have A Dream speech in Washington, said: “This  information on Dr King is beyond disturbing.It’s blatantly obvious that this person is using the sterling reputation of one of the most admired and respected men for personal attention and for what remains to be seen. “Certainly an attack on Dr King would get him attention. Fortunately, there are still people around who were close to Dr King and know him and his character.The le of a dedicated, committed, selfless man, husband, father, pastor, and civil rights leader as Reverend Dr Martin Luther King, Jr. demanded that his time and efforts meet each challenge and responsibility. His respect as a civil rights leader reached millions of people from every wall of le, race, creed, colour, gender, nationality and religion in this country and around the world.Personally, I am immensely honoured and proud to have marched with him twice. The second time was the August , , March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom in Washington DC that rocked the nation and the world and we still celebrate Dr King more than five decades later and by generations who werenapost even born.   He will continue to be celebrated for generations to come. He was that kind of man. If the FBI really had damaging evidence on Dr King they would have exposed it.From first-hand accounts to me from members of his inner circle, he was never alone even he travelled. His time was consumed in strategies, meetings and organizing in preparation for acts of civil disobedience or whatever he was called upon to do, and, of course, rest.Heaposs authored scores of books and articles, delivered speeches public and private but his best time was spent with his family, a loving we, who accompanied him often, and with his four children whom he adored.Reverend Dr Martin Luther King Jr. lived a le of selfless service to God first and to humanity. There was no room or interest for anything . To suggest that he would knowingly or willingly engage in anything illicit or criminal would discredit everything he sacriced for, stood for and ultimately died for.Yesterday, the claims ided opinion among posters on social media. Rhonda Veit said: “Do we take down the MLK memorial and rename all the streets named after MLK now ” One wrote: “Goes to show the FBI has been illegally spying on Americans all the way back to Martin Luther King.” Last year, former FBI director James Comey unapologetically and openly criticised Hoover for spying on Dr King. Describing the killer – who featured in a recent Netflix documentary and was portrayed by Zac Efron in movie Extremely Wicked, Shockingly Evil and Vile – Douglas said: “He was ruthless and he was a sadist. “He was a manipulator and a necrophiliac, but he was also very charming and gregarious. “He made a full confession to me and another agent.  “Later I had to speak to that agent because I felt he got too close to Bundy, he almost reached the point of feeling sorry for him. “Bundy would act like he was a victim, he claimed that pornography caused him to act the way he did, but that was baloney. “I had to remind the agent that Bundy was very manipulative, and that he was acting this way because they were getting ready to fry him.” And Douglas said the ploy almost worked.  “I had a call saying they wanted to keep him alive so they could study him some more, but I said no, itaposs really not necessary,” Douglas recounted. “I said Iaposd got to know him fairly well, thereaposs nothing more he can tell us.” Not long afterwards, Bundy was executed in January , aged . But Douglas said that from Bundy he learned that many killersto the scene of their crimes - a fact that helped catch killer Gary Ridgway, who was responsible for  murders.  Regarding the serial killer and rapistaposs portrayal on film, the ex-FBI man said: “I donapost think heaposs gloried in the movies, but I would have liked to see more on the impact on the victims and their families. “These people destroy lives.” Another notorious figure who Douglas interviewed, Charles Manson, is set to be portrayed in upcoming movie Once Upon a Time In Hollywood, starring Leonardo DiCaprio and Brad Pitt.  Describing his meetings with Manson, the profiler recalled: “Heaposs ft ins, it surprised me how small he was. “He stood up on a chair to exert himself over us. I knew he was going to do that because it was something he would do on his ranch. He was very dficult to interview, and some were very intimidated by him. “I interviewed him a couple of times, he said aposYou have to give me something. They know in the yard that the FBI are here.apos “He said he wanted my sunglasses, which were a pair of Ray Bans. He wanted them so he could go back and show them that heaposd ripped us off. “So I gave him the sunglasses, and he talked.”  From Manson, Douglas learned how cult members carried out the murder of actress Sharon Tate and four others at her home in August . In the hope of starting a race war, follower Lynette Fromme also attempted to assassinate President Gerald Ford in Sacramento. “I used a lot of buzz words to try and win his confidence, I tried to blend in and use the phrases I knew the Manson family used,” Douglas revealed. “In the end he said I was as nutty as him. “He was so into the helter skelter of creating a race war that his followers wanted to show they could be a somebody.”  The profiler said interviews would normally take place inside prisons at night, because the jailed monsters would often feel more at ease. When this wasnapost possible, FBI agents would dim lights to make it as dark as possible while serial killers talked. Others who Douglas interviewed in the early days of profiling included murderers Gary Ridgway – who confessed to killing  – John Wayne Gacy, who killed , Edmund Kemper and Gary Speck. He said the case that still haunts him the most is that of Lawrence Bittaker and Roy Norris, who became known as the Tool Box Killers during a killing spree which claimed the lives of five women.  They raped and killed their teenage victims over a period of five months in Southern Calornia in . “They made audio tapes of the torture, they would kick back, open a Guinness and play it over again,” Douglas said. “You could hear the screams. It was nauseating, I could only listen to a few seconds.” Douglas was the inspiration for FBI character Jack Crawford in the Hannibal Lecter movies, and worked with producers during the filming of Silence of the Lambs. To hammer home the true horror of his work, he played a segment of Bittaker and Norrisapos audio to Scott Glenn, who played Crawford, ahead of filming. “He was in tears, he was so emotional,” Douglas recalled. “Until then he said he was against the death penalty, but that changed it.” As a young agent he was determined to speak to serial killers to find outthere were any similarities that could help identy other murderers faster. From his work came the realisation that animal cruelty as a child could be a sign of evil deeds to come, and many experienced dficult childhoods. “They lack empathy, they see themselves as the victim,” said Douglas.   “They canapost identy with those they kill. If you do get them to cry, theyaposre putting on an act. “You have to show a feigned empathy with them to get what you want. Some agents would get angry and want to choke the guy, but you canapost do that. “I would find myself looking in the face of one of them and youaposd try to imagine what this face would look like when they were raping and murdering their victims, what the victim would see in the last moments of their le. “In most cases they donapost look like theyaposre capable of the crimes they committed, but you know theyaposre guilty.”  Kemper, who killed  including his grandparents and mother, was the first killer to be interviewed by Douglas and his small team. “He was talking about disposing of his motheraposs body, joking about it,” he said. “After we did that interview myself and the other agent got in the car and looked at each other, exhausted. We both needed a drink.”  Another breakthrough Douglas recalls was with Dennis Rader, who became known as the BTK killer – which stood for aposBind, Torture and Killapos. He was responsible for  deaths between  and . “I asked him what motivated him, and he said it was all about the rope,” Douglas revealed. “His thing was bondage, he sent sketches of his victims to the police.  “The main question I wanted to ask him was why he stopped for three years at a time. “In answer to that he told me heaposd got caught. One day he came home at lunchtime and put on a female victimaposs clothes and face mask, he was into autoeroticism. “His we walked in on him, but she never put two-and-two together and realised he was the BTK killer. “He said: aposJohn, I only stopped because I got caught.apos” At its height, Douglasapos department would be working on , cases a year. He believes there are between  and  serial killers carrying out murders each year in the United States - and poor communication between hundreds of law enforcement agencies means many are getting away with their crimes longer than they could be.  In Netflix show Mindhunters, which is due tofor a second series in the summer, Douglas is represented by idealistic young agent Holden Ford, played by Jonathan Groff. “The first series begins to show the toll that his work takes on him,” said Douglas. “I suffered anxiety attacks because of it. “In  I was teaching in New York City and I thought I was having a heart attack.” Days later, at the age of , he collapsed in a hotel room in Seattle. “I nearly died,” he said. “I laid on the floor for three days because I had a do not disturb sign on the door. “I was in a coma, and it needed months of rehabilitation. “I told the bureau that I couldnapostto active duty because I couldnapost lt a firearm, but they told me they just needed my brain. “At that time my brain was shot to pieces.” Nevertheless it would be more than a decade until Douglas retired from the FBI in . His first book, Mindhunter, was published the same year. Douglasapos second book, The Killer Across The Table, was released on May . On June  he will be the keynote speaker at the Eventim Apollo in Hammersmith, where members of the public can hear him speak at True Crime in Conversation.
